Help.title: Surah Distribution Graph
Help.description: A linear distribution plot comparing Surahs based on length, token density, or other selected metrics.
Help.yAxisText: Height of each bar/point represents the total token count (or selected metric) for that Surah.
Help.xAxisText: Arranged in standard Mushaf order (1. Al-Fatiha to 114. An-Nas).
Help.highlightsText: Colored markers indicate Surahs containing the currently selected Root or Lemma.

ArcFlow.title: Arc Flow Diagram
ArcFlow.modeDescription: Drag canvas to pan. Wheel or +/- to zoom.
ArcFlow.rootLegend: Bar length = frequency, color distinguishes root groups
ArcFlow.posMapping: POS mapping: N noun, V verb, ADJ adjective, PRON pronoun, P preposition, PART particle, CONJ conjunction.
ArcFlow.searchRootHint: {count} roots in scope. Type to find and pin any root to the diagram.
ArcFlow.noRootFound: No matching root found in the current scope.

Help.title: Arc Flow Diagram
Help.description: A frequency-ranked aggregate view comparing linguistic units. This shows the MOST COMMON items — not every single ayah or root. Use the root search to find specific roots that may not be in the top results.
Help.rootText: Each bar is a Root. Bar length shows frequency in scope. Curves connect roots that share the same lemma (derived form). Longer bars = more frequent roots. Use the root search input to pin a specific root to the view.
Help.posText: Each bar is a Part-of-Speech tag (N, V, ADJ, PRON, P, PART, CONJ). Curves show adjacent POS pairs within the same Ayah — showing which word types commonly appear next to each other.
Help.ayahText: Each bar is an Ayah. Curves connect ayahs when they share context tokens (same root, same lemma) across ayah boundaries. Useful for seeing thematic connections between verses.
Help.tipsText: Switch between Root, POS, and Ayah modes using the buttons in the sidebar. Use the root search (in Root mode) to find and pin roots that are not in the top results. Zoom in to see more items.

RadialSura.title: Radial Surah Map
RadialSura.hints: Hover bars and links for details. Click to pin a selection.
RadialSura.helpText: Bars = ayahs (length = token count, color = dominant POS). Dots = ayah endpoints (click to focus). Arcs = shared roots between ayahs (click to filter that root).

Help.title: Radial Surah Map
Help.description: A compact circular visualization of a single Surah's composition, plotting every Ayah (verse) and its constituent tokens.
Help.ringsText: The circle is divided into segments representing Ayahs. The number of rings corresponds to the length/complexity of the Ayah.
Help.dotsText: Each dot is a word/token. Color represents the Part of Speech (Noun, Verb, Particle).
Help.navText: Hover over dots to read the specific word and its translation. Click to focus on that token's connections.

AyahDependency.title: Ayah Dependency
AyahDependency.empty: Hover or click a token rectangle
AyahDependency.noTokens: No tokens available for {surah} in current dataset.

Help.title: Dependency Tree
Help.description: A hierarchical tree view of the grammatical structure within a single Ayah.
Help.treeText: Top nodes are the main clauses. Child nodes represent dependent words (subjects, objects, modifiers).
Help.linksText: Lines represent grammatical dependencies (e.g., 'subject of', 'modified by').

CorpusArchitecture.title: Corpus Architecture
CorpusArchitecture.subtitle: Center → Surahs → Top Roots
CorpusArchitecture.searchRootHint: {count} unique roots available. Type to search any root across all surahs.
CorpusArchitecture.noRootFound: No matching root found. Try a different Arabic root.

Help.title: Corpus Architecture Map
Help.description: An interactive radial dendrogram visualizing the hierarchical structure of the Quran, from the full Corpus down to Surahs and their most frequent Roots.
Help.hierarchyText: The center node represents the entire Quran. The first ring shows the 114 Surahs. Branching outward from each Surah are its top recurring Roots. Only the most frequent roots are shown by default — use the search box to find and highlight any root.
Help.nodesText: Colored dots are Surahs, white dots are Roots. Node size reflects token volume or root frequency. The bigger the dot, the more tokens or occurrences.
Help.interactText: Click a Surah dot to focus on it and see ALL its roots (drill down). Click again to unfocus. Click a Root dot to see its stats. Use mouse wheel to zoom, drag to pan. Use the search box in the sidebar to find and highlight any root across all surahs.
Help.tipsText: Zoom in on a focused surah to reveal more roots. The search input lets you highlight roots even if they are not in the top-10 most frequent. Click a root in the search results to highlight it everywhere.

RootFlow.title: Root to Lemma
RootFlow.notFound: Root '{root}' not found in {scope}. Try selecting 'All roots'.
RootFlow.helpLeftRight: Left column lists roots and right column lists lemmas.
RootFlow.helpBands: Each curved band maps one root to one lemma.
RootFlow.helpThickness: Thicker bands mean higher frequency in the current scope.
RootFlow.helpHover: Hover a band to preview a sample token, click to inspect it.

Help.title: Root-Lemma Flow
Help.description: A Sankey diagram tracing the flow from Arabic unique Roots to their various derived Lemmas, visualizing morphological productivity.
Help.widthText: The thickness of each band represents the Frequency of that specific Root-to-Lemma derivation.
Help.leftRightText: Left column lists Roots. Right column lists Lemmas. The flow shows which roots generate which lemmas.
Help.scopeText: Counts update based on whether you are viewing the whole Quran or a specific Surah.

RootNetwork.dragPan: Drag to pan - wheel to zoom
RootNetwork.noTokens: No token data loaded for this surah yet. Keep corpus loading, then retry this surah.
RootNetwork.noMorphology: Morphology data unavailable for this surah. Roots/lemmas require a full morphology dataset.

Help.title: Root Network Graph
Help.description: A force-directed graph revealing the linguistic connections between Roots and Lemmas based on their co-occurrence and derivation patterns.
Help.rootsText: Large central nodes are Roots (trilateral origins). Smaller peripheral nodes are Lemmas (dictionary forms) derived from them.
Help.distanceText: Shorter links indicate a stronger, more frequent connection between a Root and a Lemma.
Help.sizeText: Proportional to the total frequency of occurrences in the selected scope (Surah or full Quran).
